demographics.name: Maria Garcia
demographics.mobility: Requires walker for ambulation due to L weakness.

diagnosis.primary: Metastatic Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCLC) - Adenocarcinoma
diagnosis.symptomsAtPresentation: Worsening headaches, new onset left-sided weakness, cognitive changes.
diagnosis.baselineStatus: ECOG 2 (Ambulatory and capable of self-care but unable to carry out work activities. Up >50% of waking hours)
pathologyFindings: Biopsy of right upper lobe lung mass confirms Adenocarcinoma.
Molecular testing: EGFR exon 19 deletion positive.

treatmentPlan.concurrentChemo: None during RT. Systemic: Pembrolizumab (managed by Med Onc).
medications: Dexamethasone 4 mg PO BID (started 03/21/2025 for cerebral edema)
therapistAlerts: Fall risk; assist with all transfers to and from treatment table.
Patient may be fatigued from high disease burden.

ctSimulation.setupInstructions: Supine, neutral head position, custom thermoplastic mask for immobilization. SAD setup.
ctSimulation.referenceMarks: Mask marks aligned to room lasers at external auditory meatus (EAM). Isocenter at L0.0, L0.0, V+2.0 from reference.

dosimetry.planStatus: Final - Approved by Dr. Samuel Green
dosimetry.collAngles: 0 (shaped to include whole brain, avoid eyes)
dosimetry.constraints: Lens Max < 8 Gy; Optic Nrv Max < 25 Gy. All constraints met.
dosimetry.planNotes: Standard palliative 10-fraction WBRT. Hippocampal avoidance not indicated given palliative intent and extent of disease.

fractions.generalSideEffects: Moderate fatigue, pre-existing L weakness noted.
fractions.dailyNotes: First fraction delivered. Patient required assistance for transfer. Tolerated mask and treatment well. Son present at appointment.
OTV today. Patient reports subjective improvement in headache. Neurologic status stable. Mild hair thinning beginning.

fractions.generalSideEffects: Significant fatigue. Mild skin erythema in temporal regions.
fractions.dailyNotes: Final fraction completed. Patient is relieved. Significant alopecia noted. Will continue Dexamethasone taper as per Med Onc. Follow-up scheduled.

imagingAndReports.summary: Multiple new enhancing lesions throughout cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum, consistent with metastatic disease. Largest lesion in the right parietal lobe measuring 2.5 cm with significant surrounding vasogenic edema.

reportDetails.protocol: MRI Brain with and without Gadolinium
reportDetails.findings: At least 10 discrete, ring-enhancing lesions are identified throughout the supratentorial and infratentorial compartments, consistent with metastatic deposits. The largest lesion is in the right parietal lobe, measuring 2.5 cm. There is extensive associated T2/FLAIR hyperintensity representing vasogenic edema, causing mass effect and effacement of adjacent sulci.
reportDetails.impression: Widespread brain metastases, consistent with Stage IV lung cancer. Findings warrant urgent palliative whole brain radiation therapy.

labResults.notes: Mild hyperglycemia likely secondary to Dexamethasone. Otherwise WNL.

progressNotes.author: Dr. David Roberts (Med Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient with Stage IV NSCLC presents with new, progressive neurologic symptoms. MRI confirms extensive brain metastases with significant edema. Starting high-dose Dexamethasone and referring urgently to Radiation Oncology for palliative WBRT. Discussed palliative goals of care with patient and family; DNR/DNI status confirmed.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Green (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Patient seen for urgent consult for symptomatic brain metastases. Reviewed imaging. Plan is for palliative WBRT, 30 Gy in 10 fractions, to begin as soon as possible. Discussed goals (symptom relief, delaying neurologic decline), procedure, and common side effects (fatigue, hair loss, skin reaction). Patient and family agree to proceed. Simulation scheduled for tomorrow.

progressNotes.author: Dr. Samuel Green (Rad Onc)
progressNotes.summary: Maria completed her course of palliative WBRT today. She has had a good clinical response with significant improvement in her headaches and stabilization of her neurologic deficits. She experienced expected fatigue and alopecia. She will follow up with Medical Oncology to continue systemic therapy and begin a slow steroid taper. Hospice services will continue to be involved for supportive care.

patientEducation.goalsDiscussed: To relieve symptoms such as headache and weakness caused by brain metastases and to delay the progression of neurological symptoms. This is a palliative treatment intended to improve quality of life.
patientEducation.sideEffectsReviewed: Common acute side effects include fatigue, hair loss (which may be permanent), and a mild skin reaction on the scalp. Less common effects include nausea and worsening of headaches, which are managed with medication. Long-term cognitive changes are possible but less of a concern given the palliative setting.
patientEducation.safetyConsiderations: The importance of taking Dexamethasone exactly as prescribed to control brain swelling. Report any new or worsening neurological symptoms (e.g., increased weakness, new seizures, severe headache) immediately. Due to weakness and fatigue, fall precautions are very important.
patientEducation.patientResponsibilities: Attend all daily radiation appointments. Report symptoms to the team. Take medications as prescribed. Adhere to fall precautions at home.
